article.title: Redshifted X-rays from the material accreting onto TW Hya: evidence of a low-latitude accretion spot

multiple_choice_question.text: What types of spectra are shown in Figure 1 for TW Hya?
choices: Medium-Energy Grating (MEG) and High-Energy Grating (HEG) Spectra

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 2 illustrate in relation to the Chandra/HETGS?
choices: The effective area of the instrument at different wavelengths.
The predicted Gaussian width (Ïƒ) of the Line Response Function (LRF) for both gratings.
The absolute wavelength accuracy of the instrument.
The relationship between the signal-to-noise ratio and exposure time.

multiple_choice_question.text: What information does Figure 3 provide about TW Hya\'s X-ray emission?
choices: The variation of emission measure with time.
The distribution of X-ray emitting plasma in temperature, highlighting accretion and coronal components.
The relative flux contribution of cool and hot lines.
The Doppler shift of emission lines originating from different plasma components.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the red dashed line in each panel of Figure 4 represent?
choices: The average velocity of the hot plasma component.
The predicted pre-shock velocity of accreting material.
The average velocity of the cool plasma component.
The radial velocity of the Earth at the time of observation.
